attributes.title: Investigating the Effects of Linguistic Knowledge on Apparent Motion in Chinese Characters Across Visual Orientations
attributes.description: “Chinese and Americans see opposite apparent motions in a Chinese character” by Tse and Cavanagh (2000) found that Chinese speakers report observing an apparent motion of the last stroke in the presentation of a Chinese character that accords with standard writing practices, while Americans report apparent motion in the opposite direction in accordance with Gestalt grouping principles. They take this as evidence for a top-down effect of linguistic knowledge on perceptual processing. Li and Yeh (2003) replicate and expand upon these results, finding evidence that this effect is only observed when the character is written in chirographic script (where stroke directional information is preserved) and when the strokes are presented in the order in which they are written. We will examine whether or not this effect persists when the orientation of the character is manipulated.

q1.value: Margaret Bigler, Polyphony Bruna, Ryan  Cherry, Griffin Scott-Rifer, Jan Andrews, Joshua de Leeuw

q2.value:
If the effect is as reported in the original studies, then manipulating the orientation of the character should not impact the observed effect: Chinese speakers should report apparent motion in the direction corresponding to how the stroke would be written and Americans should report apparent motion in the opposite direction (corresponding to Gestalt grouping principles). This is because the linguistic knowledge that is responsible for the perceptual effect is preserved when visual angle is altered (for example, I am able to read a word written upside down).

If orientation does impact the reported apparent motion in Chinese speakers, then the effect cannot be due to a top-down effect of linguistic knowledge of the character.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q5.value: Participants will be unaware of the hypothesis of the study.

question.value: Participants will report on four trials corresponding to the four orientations (0°, 90°, 180°, 270°). In each trial, a fixation cross will appear on screen before being replaced by the full character in the orientation corresponding to the condition. The character will then disappear and then reappear stroke-by-stroke corresponding to the correct stroke order for the character (the order in which the strokes would be written). Each stroke will appear all at once and will remain on-screen as additional strokes appear. After the last stroke appears, the participant will be asked to report the direction in which they perceived the last stroke to appear. The completed character will remain on-screen while participants respond. Participants will be given 60 seconds to respond.

q7.value: We will counterbalance the order in which participants are presented with the four possible orientations.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Recruitment: Subjects will be recruited online using Prolific.
Inclusion/Exclusion rules: Participants must be between 18 - 80 years old and be native Mandarin or English speakers. In the absence of enough Mandarin-speaking participants, data collection will open to native Japanese-speaking participants as well (this is justified in the context of our study because i. our study only requires native knowledge of the single Chinese character we use and ii. this character is identical in appearance, stroke-order, and meaning across the two languages). Mandarin and Japanese-speaking participants will be excluded if they report not having at least 10 years of experience writing characters or if they report using a different stroke order than the standard used in this study. Any participant who reports accurately guessing the purpose of the study or who reports not faithfully completing the study as per the instructions will be excluded. Participants will be excluded if their reaction time does not fall reasonably within the distribution of reaction times for both groups combined. Exclusion on the basis of reaction time will be done prior to data analysis to avoid bias.

Study timeline: Participants will be run until our desired sample size is achieved or funds are exhausted.

q12.value: The original study used a sample of 20 participants. An online crowd-sourcing method of data collection will allow us to achieve a sample size of 200.

q13.value: Data collection will end after funds are exhausted, we are unable to maintain equally sized groups, or when our reported sample size is reached.

question.value:
The manipulated variable is the orientation of the character: 0°, 90°, 180°, and 270°.
Visual stimuli: the Chinese character “雪” will be presented first all at once in the orientation corresponding to the condition. The character will then disappear and reappear stroke-by-stroke, with each stroke appearing all at once and remaining on screen as additional strokes appear.
Response on perceived direction of motion. We will also measure reaction time in order to exclude unreasonable reaction times.
We will not be using any indices.

The upright condition (0°) will be isolated to determine if our study produced the effect reported in the original study by using a Bayesian categorical regression model with group as a predictor.

We will then generate a Bayesian categorical regression model with group and orientation as predictors for reported direction of motion.

The first analysis (without orientation) will include group as a random factor. The second analysis (with orientation) will include both group and orientation as random factors. If the model is unable to converge with orientation as a random factor, then it will be omitted as a random factor.

q18.value: For our analysis of group and orientation, participant responses will first be translated relative to the orientation of the character. For example, the response “down to up” on a character presented at 90° will be translated to the response “left to right.”

q19.value: We will use the standard p<0.05 criteria for determining significance.

q20.value: No exclusion will occur post data analysis. See “Data Collection” section for pre-analysis exclusion criteria.

q21.value: Participants with incomplete or missing data will be excluded and noted in the paper.

q22.value: There are no plans for any exploratory analysis.

q23.value:

Tse, P. U., & Cavanagh, P. (2000). Chinese and Americans see opposite apparent motions in a Chinese character. Cognition, 74(3). doi: 10.1016/s0010-0277(99)00065-7

attributes.title: Utterance informativity
attributes.description: Communication depends in part on the hope that people will tell us things we’re interested in with language providing a channel by which speakers can convey, among other things, newsworthy and informative messages. Despite this, research often emphasises the role of predictability, showing that comprehenders make fast and sophisticated use of knowledge about typical situations to shape their expectations about upcoming words in fine-grained and context-driven ways. This new study contrasts these two dimensions, distinguishing knowledge about situation plausibility from knowledge about what people actually choose to talk about.

q1.value: Hannah Rohde, Michael Franke, Jet Hoek, Maayan Keshev

q2.value:
General hypothesis:
People use real-world knowledge to estimate probable situations, and use these guesses to estimate what kind of messages would be worth uttering.

Specific hypothesis:
When prompted to guess what kind of situation a speaker will describe, participants will more often select a high (i.e. more remarkable) number when the speaker announces something to a large audience compared to when they report something to one person.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Our forced-choice task has a within subjects design with 1 factor (audience size) with two levels ('one person'  vs 'everyone')

q7.value: The condition participants see each item in and the order in which they see the items will be completely randomized.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will recruit participants through Amazon Mechanical Turk. 

Before the actual experiment starts, participants fill out a background questionnaire. Since we only want to include native speakers of English, participants will be excluded from the analysis if they answered 'yes' to the following question:

"Was there any other language besides English spoken in the home before the age of 6?"

Note: participants who answer 'yes' to this question will still complete the experiment and get paid for doing so.

In addition, we will include 4 'catch' trials that have obvious correct answers (e.g., the number of hours in a day) to check participants' performance. Participants who do not get the catch trials correct will be excluded from the analysis.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 150 native speakers of English.

q12.value: The experiment was structured in parallel to a previous experiment, manipulating the speaker's initiative (same number of experimental items). Since effect size for the current experiment is unknown, and based on our intuitions regarding the effect in each case, we use 50% more participants than in the speaker initiative case (i.e. 150 participants) to obtain high enough power.

question.value:
Participants are presented with forced-choice fill-in-the-blank items. We manipulate whether a character is said to announce something TO EVERYONE or tells it to ONE PERSON.

     Erin is a first grade student in primary school.
     Erin has an uncle, Josh.
     Yesterday, at the office,  Josh stood up and said to everyone that there are ______ children 
     in Erin's class. /
     Yesterday, at the office, Josh said to me that there are ______ children in Erin's class.

                            20           28

Our outcome variable is the number participants select. In each item, participants can choose from 2 numbers: an average or a high number (Items are based on a previous experiment, information about the choice of target values is available there: https://osf.io/dhm5g

We will analyze participants' responses (average vs. high) using mixed effects logistic regression.

The predictor variable Audience size (to everyone vs. to one person) will be dummy coded and centered. We will include random item and participant variables.

In case the model does not converge, we will remove the correlation between the slope and the intercept for the random variable with the least explained variance. If the model still not converges after the correlation between the random slope and the random intercept has been removed for each variable, we will remove the random variable with the least explained variance (following Barr et al. 2013).

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the mixed effects logistic regression analysis suggests that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

attributes.title: Values and preferences towards medical cannabis among patients with chronic pain and their carers: protocol for a mixed methods systematic review
attributes.description: To investigate values and preferences related to medical cannabis for chronic pain among patients (including children, adolescents and adults) with chronic pain (including cancer or non-cancer chronic pain) and their carers.

q1.value: Linan Zeng, Xiaoqin Wang, Natasha Kithulegoda, Silvana Agterberg, Lyubov Lytvyn, Shelly-Anne Li, Anja Fog Heen, Thomas Agoritsas, Gordon Guyatt, Jason Busse, Yaad Shergill, Meysam Abdar

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A mixed methods systematic review.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: We will include all eligible studies

question.value: Reviewers will extract data from eligible studies independently and in duplicate, using a standardized spreadsheet in Microsoft Excel that includes the following information: study identification, objectives or research questions, population characteristics, design (e.g. cross-sectional survey, cohort study, randomized controlled trial) and methods (for qualitative study, e.g. focus group, Delphi method, structured individual interview; for quantitative study, e.g. discrete choice, standard gamble, time trade-off), risk of bias or methodological limitations, and findings. Disagreements will be resolved by consensus or consultation with an adjudicator.

We will apply a 4-step approach for data synthesis and analysis, based on the methods from a previous values and preferences review. First, we will select 2 eligible articles per study design, identify key themes, and code them in categories. Second, we will use these categories to design ad hoc data extraction forms. Third, using an iterative process, we will compare the key themes of the categories identified across all studies and develop analytic themes. Fourth, we will apply mixed review approach to transform the quantitative data into qualitative data.

For quantitative studies, we will assess the certainty of evidence for each review finding according to GRADE domains (i.e., risk of bias, imprecision, inconsistency, indirectness, and publication bias). For qualitative studies, we will assess the certainty of evidence according to GRADE-CERQual (Confidence in the Evidence from Reviews of Qualitative Research) domains (i.e., methodological limitations, relevance, coherence, adequacy and dissemination bias). Findings will initially be considered as high certainty and will be downgraded by 1 or more levels if serious or several minor or moderate concerns are detected in 1 or more domains. Ratings will range from high to very low.

q23.value:
Risk of bias/methodological limitation of individual study

For quantitative studies, we will use the GRADE (Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation) approach to assess risk of bias of included studies. We will specifically examine the following domains: participant selection, completeness of data, measurement instrument, participants’ understanding of the methodology, and data analysis.

For qualitative studies, we will use the Critical Appraisal Skills Programme (CASP) checklist to assess methodological quality of individual qualitative studies. The CASP consists of the following items: aim of the research, qualitative methodology appropriateness, research design, appropriate recruitment strategy, data collection, investigator- participant relationship, ethical issues, data analysis, findings, and value of the research. If more than 2 items on the CASP checklist are rated with ‘serious concerns’, we will label the study as one with serious methodological limitations”. If 2 items on the CASP checklist are rated with ‘serious concerns’ we will label the study as one with “moderate methodological limitations”.

attributes.title: COVID-19 interdependence and elevation
attributes.description: This study seeks to examine consequences of understanding and recognizing extra-individual factors that detract from well-being in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. In addition, instances of moral elevation, occurring in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, will be examined to enhance understanding of elevation.

q2.value:
Interdependence-related Hs:
H: Participants in the positive interdependence condition will exhibit higher levels of gratitude and prosocial behavior than participants in either the control or negative interdependence conditions. The effect of condition on prosocial behavior will be mediated by gratitude.
H: Participants in the negative interdependence condition will exhibit higher levels of resentment than participants in either the control or positive interdependence conditions.
H: The effect of the negative interdependence condition on resentment will be moderated by the extent to which participants believe others will suffer as a result of COVID-19 such that the more participants believe others will suffer, the less resentment they will experience.
Elevation-related Hs:
H: Older adults are more likely to be mentioned as recipients than givers of help.
H: Elevation is greater if the recipient is under 18 or over 65 than if they are middle aged.
H: Elevation is greater if the helper is under 18 or over 65 than if they are middle-aged.
H: Elevation is greater for middle-aged and older adult respondents than for younger adult respondents when negative interdependence has been primed whereas there is no difference in the other two experimental conditions.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three experimental conditions: a passive control; a positive interdependence condition, in which they will consider ways in which other people benefit them; and a negative interdependence condition, in which they will consider ways in which extra-individual factors (people, events, etc.) detract from their well-being. All participants will then respond to items concerning gratitude, resentment, prosocial outcomes, an elevation prompt, and elevation measures.

q7.value: Randomization will occur via the Qualtrics platform at the level of the participant.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: 240 participants will be recruited through mTurk. Participants must be 18 years of age or older, residing in the United States, English-literate, and must not know anyone who has been hospitalized or otherwise suffered grave medical consequences as a result of COVID-19. Participants will be compensated $1.75 for completing the study.

Gratitude: gratitude adjectives checklist, GQ-6; Resentment: 4 select items from Gratitude, Resentment, Appreciation Test; Prosocial outcome: Aspiration Index community feeling subscale; Elevation: 19 items previously used by Thomson and Siegel. Original items concerning effects of COVID-19 relating to self and others.
Additional demographic items.

Between-groups analyses will be conducted to examine hypothesized differences in gratitude, resentment, and prosocial outcomes. Mediation analysis will examine the mediating role of gratitude in the positive interdependence--prosocial relationship.

attributes.title: Functional and Quality of Life Outcomes After In Hospital CPR: A Systematic Review
attributes.description: We are performing a systematic review of all studies that report quality of life outcomes for patients who have received CPR in hospital.

q1.value: Tolu Adewole, Daniel Kobewka, Pete Wegier, Daniel I McIsaac, Kwado Kyeremanteng, Sunita Mulpuru, Dean Ferguson, Shannon Fernando

q2.value: If seriously ill patients have CPR, then their functional status and neurological status after CPR may stay as it was or worsen after CPR.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We are conducting a systematic review on patients (18 years or older) who experience in-hospital cardiac arrest and received cardiopulmonary resuscitation. We want to know what the functional, neurological and quality of life outcomes for these patients who survive in-hospital CPR are. 

The main outcome of interest includes:
Functional status as defined as the ability to independently complete activities of daily living.
Neurological status measured using CPC scores, Glasgow coma scores
Discharge disposition measured by where patients are discharged to either their home, nursing facilities, other inpatient hospital, long-term care home

Please find our systematic review protocol attached.

q7.value: N/A - This is a systematic review

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q9.value: We are performing a systematic review with meta analysis.  All data already exists but has not been compiled or analyzed. The data for this review has not yet been compiled so no one has  been able to look at patterns or summary statistics.

question.value:
The search strategy was developed by an Information Specialist with clinical input. The search strategy we used for MEDLINE(R) is below.  For other databases we translated the same search strategy. The full MEDLINE search strategy is attached (Appendix 1)

Ovid MEDLINE(R) ALL <1946 to February 19, 2020>
Embase Classic+Embase <1947 to February 19, 2020>
EBM Reviews - Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials 
CINAHL

Inclusion criteria: Studies with patients who experienced cardiac arrest while in hospital and received CPR. Patients must be at least 18 years old. Studies must report either a quality of life outcome, physical or cognitive functional outcome either during hospital stay, at discharge or post discharge. Studies including both in- and out-of hospital cardiac arrests will be considered for inclusion if data from the IHCA sub population could be extracted and computed separately. Included studies must have all or a majority of data collected after 1995 because this is when defibrillation was first recommended for ventricular fibrillation. We will limit language of publication to English and French. We will include both observational cohort and interventional study designs. Interventional studies must evaluate treatments post arrest (hypothermia or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation etc.) 

Exclusion criteria: Studies including only out of hospital cardiac arrest patients and those conducted on pediatric populations. Studies that did not report quality of life outcomes such as functional status were excluded. Reviews, case reports, and case series were also excluded.

Data Abstraction 
Two reviewers will independently abstract data in duplicate. We will abstract the following data elements from each study: 1) Study characteristics: Year of publication, years of data collection, country, setting and hospital type, study design 2) Population characteristics: age, sex, admission diagnosis, comorbidity measures, baseline QoL and function 3) Arrest characteristics: initial shockable rhythm, witness arrested or found pulseless. 

We will use a two-stage review process by two independent reviewers, managed with Covidence®. Stage 1 will be screening abstracts and titles for eligibility. In stage 2, we will screen the full journal articles identified as potentially eligible in Stage 1. Data extraction will be done in duplicate using Microsoft Excel®.  Discrepancies between the 2 data extractors will be resolved with consensus.

q11.value: This is a systematic review. We will include as many studies that meet our inclusion criteria.

question.value: Our main outcome will be QoL and function measured by the SF-36, EQ5-D, WHODAS 2.0 or Cerebral Performance Category (CPC) score measured at the time of hospital discharge, 1-month post CPR and 1 year after receiving CPR. Our secondary outcomes will be any study defined measures of physical function, cognitive function or quality of life. We will also report changes in any of the above measures prior to receiving CPR Our main outcome will be QoL and function measured by the SF-36, EQ5-D, WHODAS 2.0 or Cerebral Performance Category (CPC) score measured at the time of hospital discharge, 1-month post CPR and 1 year after receiving CPR. Our secondary outcomes will be any study defined measures of physical function, cognitive function or quality of life. We will also report changes in any of the above measures prior to receiving CPR

For our main analysis we will present forest plots of unadjusted and adjusted estimates for each primary outcome. We will present pooled adjusted and unadjusted estimates if statistical heterogeneity is less than 75% when estimates are pooled with a random effects model.  Adjusted models must at a minimum include age and sex. Secondary outcomes will also be presented in a forest plot and pooled in the same manner as the primary outcomes if multiple studies use the same outcome.  

For the dichotomized outcomes we will present the estimates in a forest plot showing the proportion who experienced the outcomes and we will perform meta-analysis of adjusted and unadjusted estimates. 

All meta-analysis will be done using random effects models using RevMan5.  We will report the I2 as a measure of statistical heterogeneity.

attributes.title: The effect of social dominance orientation on implicit and explicit language attitudes towards spoken Northern and Southern English
attributes.description: This project explores the effect of social dominance orientation on the explicit and implicit attitudes of Northern and Southern English speakers towards these two varieties of spoken English. To do this, it utilises an auditory implicit association test to assess associations of spoken words with competence-related adjectives.

q2.value:
H1: English nationals will show an implicit preference for Southern English speech 

H2: English nationals will show an explicit preference for their own variety of English speech

H3: Strength of in-group solidarity with the North of England or the South of England will predict an explicit preference for their own variety of English speech

H4: Females will hold significantly more positive explicit attitudes towards Northern English speech 

H5: Younger English nationals will hold significantly more positive explicit attitudes towards Northern English speech 

H6: Higher levels of social dominance orientation (SDO) will correlate with a stronger implicit preference for Southern English speech 

H7: The effect of English nationals’ implicit preference for Southern English speech will depend on levels of social dominance orientation. Specifically, high levels of SDO will predict an implicit preference for Southern English speech among self-identifying speakers of Northern English. By contrast, low levels of SDO will predict an implicit preference for Northern English speech among self-identifying speakers of Northern English.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is an observational study.

For the first part we measure explicit attitudes (competence) towards Northern and Southern English speech (on a 100-point scale) along with demographics, strength of identification (ingroup solidarity), and social dominance orientation. The measures used are attached here.

For the second part participants will complete a standard IAT task but with audio stimuli (Northern and Southern English spoken words). Participants will be counterbalanced into left and right conditions (associating the left or right keys with either positive/negative words or Northern English/Southern English sounds) and this will be reversed for the second part of the experiment. The experiment consists of 5 blocks as is common in IAT studies. The IAT experiment is attached as an OpenSesame file.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Approximately 150 participants will be recruited for this research. Participants will be from the UK, must identify as English nationals and in turn, as speakers of Northern or Southern English. They must be over 18 years old. Participants will be recruited online via online advertisements and recruitment platforms (e.g. surveryswap.io and/or Prolific).

q12.value: Based on the 2x2 ANOVA for H7 we will need at least 120 participants (30pp per cell) to ensure 80% power (VanVoorhis & Morgan, 2007). We aim to recruit slightly more than 120 participants to allow for exclusion of participants with missing data, for example.

question.value: N/A.

- Social dominance orientation
- Strength of identification as speaker of Northern English or Southern English
- Gender
- Age
- Geographical provenance
- Birth location
- Explicit attitudes to Northern English speech and Southern English speech
- Implicit associations with Northern English speech and Southern English speech to competence-related words (D-score)

The scoring method devised by Greenwald, Nosek, & Banaji, (2003) will be used to calculate D-scores.

SDO scores will be calculated using the mean value of the items.

H1: English nationals will show an implicit preference for Southern English speech

H2: English nationals will show an explicit preference for their own variety of English speech

H3: Strength of in-group solidarity with the north of England or the south of England will predict an explicit preference for their own variety of English speech
Test: ANOVA (IV: Type of English spoken; DV: IAT d-score/explicit attitude score; covariate: strength of identification)

H4.  Younger English nationals will hold significantly more positive explicit attitudes towards Northern English speech
Test: Correlation

H5.	Females will hold significantly more positive explicit attitudes towards Northern English speech compared to males.
Test: independent groups T-test

H6.	Higher levels of social dominance orientation (SDO) will correlate with a stronger implicit preference for Southern English
Test: Bivariate correlation

H7.	The effect of English nationals’ implicit preference for Southern English speech will depend on levels of social dominance orientation. Specifically, high levels of SDO will predict an implicit preference for Southern English speech among self-identifying speakers of Northern English. By contrast, low levels of SDO will predict an implicit preference for Northern English speech among self-identifying speakers of Northern English.
Test: ANOVA (Factors: Type of English, Level of SDO; DV: IAT d-score).

q18.value: For H7 we will perform a median split on the SDO scores.

attributes.title: Behavioral Online Study: Emotional Consequences of Dishonesty
attributes.description: The aim of this study is to test whether the results of the previous hypothetical studies will replicate when measuring actual behaviors. Participants will play a coin-toss task which induces a conflict between being honest and being dishonest for the benefit of a charity (altruistic dishonesty) or for the benefit of oneself (egoistic dishonesty). Next, participants will report their emotions.

attributes.title: Creativity and Thought Constraint
attributes.description: According to the Dynamic Framework view of mind wandering (Christoff et al., 2016), unconstrained thought should be associated creativity. In a prior study, we manipulated rates of thought constraint using an n-back working memory task and found it to have no influence on performance in a post-intervention creativity task (an alternative uses task). However, we did find that creativity scores overall were negatively associated with self-reported rates of unconstrained thought (regardless of which n-back working memory task participants were assigned to). In this study, we further examine the relationship between thought constraint and creativity.  Participants will complete 10 alternative uses tasks. Following each task we will present thought probes to gauge thought constraint during the previous task.

q2.value:
Dynamic Framework (Christoff et al., 2016) predicts that unconstrained thought will be positively associated with creativity.

Given our prior findings, we hypothesize that creativity will be negatively associated with unconstrained thought.

question.value: Within subjects design with 10 AUT items / 10 thought probes.

question.value: Participants will be recruited on Amazon Mechanical Turk and compensated $2 for their participation ($8/hour). Workers must have completed more than 5000 HITs with 98% approval to participate.

We will measure response creativity and fluency in the alternative uses task (creativity of responses as determined by trained raters and fluency/number of responses).
We will measure thought probe responses (binary, yes/no)

We will correlate average AUT performance and proportion of unconstrained thoughts across the entire experiment.
We will also use a linear mixed-effects model with AUT scores as the dependent variable, thought constraint (yes/no) as a fixed effect, AUT object, trial, and subject as random effects.

q19.value: We will use p-values with a .05 cut-off criteria (two-tailed test).

q20.value:
We will exclude participants who do not complete the study in full.
We will exclude AUT trials where participants fail to give at least two responses and exclude participants who fail to provide sufficient responses to at least 7/10 AUT trials.

attributes.title: The effect of individual differences in Episodic Future Thought on sketching true and false intentions
attributes.description:
This is the second study in a series of studies exploring whether differences in Episodic Future Thought ability (EFT; i.e., the ability to mentally visualise future events) affects the ability to lie about intentions. In study 1, we used 4 EFT tasks to examine which EFT measure best correlated with lying ability. The correlation between the 4 tasks was lower than we would have expected if the tasks were all measuring EFT. We therefore speculated that the 4 measures might be measuring some other aspect of the EFT tasks (e.g. talkativeness), rather than EFT itself. To test this, we intend to replicate our previous study, but ask participants to report the EFT via sketches as well as verbally. That way, if the verbal EFT task is predictive of lying in sketches, we will then know the task is measuring more than talkativeness.   
This study consists of 3 parts. Part A of the study consists of 2 tasks: a lying about intentions task and an episodic details task. Participants will then take part in the same lying about intentions experiment as study 1, which is largely based on Granhag and Knieps (2011). Participants will be asked to plan a mock criminal event (placing a memory stick containing illegal material on a specific shelf in the physics section of the university library) and plan a cover story to tell the interviewer in case they are intercepted.  Participants will also be asked to plan one of five randomly selected innocent tasks, such as buying two gifts for a friend from a local shop.  Just before the participant leaves the building, they will be intercepted by an interviewer and taken to a nearby room for questioning. The interviewer will be blind to which tasks are actually part of the study and the participant’s task is to deceive the interviewer successfully. The interviewer will first ask the participant about their intentions, followed by questions about any mental image that was activated during the planning of their task. Finally, participants will be asked to sketch a picture of their most dominant mental image of what it will be like when they complete their task. Participants will then return to the original room and complete a detailed post-interview questionnaire beginning with questions directly related to EFT, followed by questions adapted from the Memory Characteristics Questionnaire (MCQ, Johnson, Foley, Suengas & Raye, 1988) relating to the phenomenological characteristics of their most dominant mental image including perceptual details.
To assess participant’s EFT ability, participants will complete an episodic details task adapted from D’Argembeau, Ortoleva, Jumentier and Van der Linden’s (2010) study. The episodic details task requires participants to imagine a possible situation that they may encounter in the future (‘imagine something you will do on your next holiday’). Participants will be told to describe the specific event as if they were physically present in the situation including as many details as possible. Participants will then respond to a series of questions adapted from the MCQ (Johnson et al, 1988) indicating their phenomenological experience of the task.  In the previous study (study 1), this EFT task was the most predictive measure of the amount of details and number of words participants used, when describing their true and deceptive intention. Participants will also complete the revised Hexaco Personality Inventory (Ashton & Lee, 2009) in which they will rate 60 statements about themselves from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). This questionnaire measures six broad personality factors: Honesty-humility, emotionality, extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness and openness to experience.
Participants will then take part in the same ‘intent to deceive’ experiment as study 1, which is largely based on Granhag and Knieps (2011). Participants will be asked to plan a mock criminal event (placing a memory stick containing illegal material on a specific shelf in the physics section of the university library) and plan a cover story in case they are intercepted.  Participants will also be asked to plan one of five randomly selected innocent tasks, such as buying two gifts for a friend from a local shop.  Just before the participant leaves the building, they will be intercepted by an interviewer and taken to a nearby room for questioning. The interviewer will first ask the participant about their intentions, followed by questions about any mental image that was activated during the planning of their task. Finally, participants will be asked to sketch an image of their most dominant mental image of what it will be like when they complete their task. Participants will then return to the original room and complete a detailed post-interview questionnaire beginning with questions directly related to EFT, followed by questions relating to the phenomenological characteristics of EFT.
In part B of this study, we will ask a separate group of participants to rate the veracity of the verbal descriptions of the truthful and deceptive tasks provided in part A. Participants will also rate their confidence in their veracity judgements as well as the plausibility of the story.
In part C of this study, we will ask participants to rate the veracity of the sketches collected part A. We will also ask them to rate the abstractness of the sketches. This task is a replication of Calderon, Giolla, Ask and Granhag, (2018). Calderon et al. found that participants judged drawings of false intentions as more abstract than true intentions drawings.

In part C of this study, we will ask participants to rate the veracity of the sketches collected part A. We will also ask them to rate the abstractness of the sketches. This task is a replication of Calderon, Giolla, Ask and Granhag, (2018). Calderon et al. found that participants judged drawings of false intentions as more abstract than true intentions drawings.

q4.value:
Main effect hypotheses

Veracity
Participants will give more details in their truthful interview/sketch/self-report than in their deception interview/sketch/self-report. Truthful mental image sketches will be judged as more concrete and deceptive mental image sketches as more abstract.

EFT ability 
Individuals with higher episodic future thought ability will give more details in their interviews/sketches than those with lower EFT ability. 

Modality Sketching/Speaking/Self report
Participants will give more details in their verbal accounts than their sketches. Perceptual details given in the verbal and self-report of the episodic details task will correlate. Self-reports of the mental image formed in the episodic details task will also correlate with self-reports of the truthful and deceptive mental images.

Personality
Individuals who scored higher on extraversion will use more words when describing their truthful and deceptive tasks and mental images.

Interactions
The previous study found main effects of veracity and EFT and a partial interaction effect. Those with higher EFT ability were rated as more believable when they were lying (but not when they were telling the truth) vs. those with lower EFT ability. Those with higher EFT ability also had their stories rated as more plausible when they were lying vs. those with lower EFT ability. We predict a similar interaction in this study: the differences in truthful and deceptive accounts (as measured by level of detail and word count) will be smaller for individuals with higher EFT ability vs. those with lower EFT ability. We are however, unsure whether this is a modality specific interaction. We hypothesise that there may be a 3-way interaction effect between veracity, modality (sketching/speaking) and EFT. Those with higher EFT ability may have their deceptive verbal (but not their deceptive sketches) rated as more truthful than those with lower EFT ability. Those with higher EFT ability may have their deceptive sketches judged as more concrete versus those with lower EFT ability.

question.value: The study will be advertised on the Lancaster University SONA research participation system. q13.value: Our target sample size is 88 participants for study A, 135 participants for study B, and 80 participants for study C. We will attempt to recruit 10% more than this, assuming that not all participants will complete the entire task.

q14.value: For study A, G*power was used to conduct an a priori power analysis, using the exact test family and a linear multiple regression as the test. The test assumed two tailed, H0 of 0, and 3 predictors (the EFT test, the personality questionnaire and the sketching task). Alpha was set at 0.05 and power was set at 0.95. We assumed a H1 variance explained of 0.2. This analysis suggested 88 participants would be needed. For study B, 135 participants will be recruited. We chose this sample size so that all audio recordings will be rated by at least 15 participants. For study C we decided that each of the 176 sketches derived from study A should be judged at least 20 times, therefore 80 participants will be recruited to each judge 44 sketches.

question.value: We manipulated the veracity of the conditions i.e., truthful and deceptive, the modality (verbal/sketch/self-report) and the order of task presentation (1/2/3/4).

We will measure participants EFT ability using an episodic details task (D’Argembeau et al, 2010) and a memory characteristics questionnaire (Johnson et al, 1988). Participants will also complete a 60 item Hexaco personality questionnaire (Ashton & Lee, 2009). We will also measure participants subjective views of their tasks by asking them to complete a post interview questionnaire after each interview including questions directly related to EFT (e.g., ‘To what extent did you form a mental image while planning your errand/cover story?’); the phenomenological characteristics of EFT (adapted from the MCQ); i.e., sensory details, spatial details and temporal details.  Participants will also be asked how well they pre-experienced their future event/cover story, and lastly they will be asked to rate the difficultly of the EFT question asked in the interview (‘Did you, at any point during your planning evoke mental image of an event?’).

A Wilcoxon signed-rank test will be performed on the manipulation checks to ensure the task instructions were understood. Wilcoxon signed-rank tests will also be performed on participants subjective experiences of their truthful and deceptive interviews. A McNemar test will be used to compare reports of the activation of a mental image in the interviews. Wilcoxon signed-rank tests will be used to compare the amount of perceptual details and number of words participants provided in the truthful and deceptive interviews. Pearson bi variate correlations will be conducted on the personality questionnaire, EFT scores, level of detail and word count. Linear regressions will test whether EFT and/or personality scores predict level of detail and word count in both modalities (verbal and sketching). Correlations and regressions will be used to test whether judgements of sketches relate to EFT and/or personality scores. Multiple comparisons false discover rate will be used to adjust p values.

This is a replication of a previous study with the added element of sketching.

registration_responses.q1: The effect of individual differences in Episodic Future Thought on sketching true and false intentions
registration_responses.q3:
This is the second study in a series of studies exploring whether differences in Episodic Future Thought ability (EFT; i.e., the ability to mentally visualise future events) affects the ability to lie about intentions. In study 1, we used 4 EFT tasks to examine which EFT measure best correlated with lying ability. The correlation between the 4 tasks was lower than we would have expected if the tasks were all measuring EFT. We therefore speculated that the 4 measures might be measuring some other aspect of the EFT tasks (e.g. talkativeness), rather than EFT itself. To test this, we intend to replicate our previous study, but ask participants to report the EFT via sketches as well as verbally. That way, if the verbal EFT task is predictive of lying in sketches, we will then know the task is measuring more than talkativeness. 
  
This study consists of 3 parts. Part A of the study consists of 2 tasks: a lying about intentions task and an episodic details task. Participants will then take part in the same lying about intentions experiment as study 1, which is largely based on Granhag and Knieps (2011). Participants will be asked to plan a mock criminal event (placing a memory stick containing illegal material on a specific shelf in the physics section of the university library) and plan a cover story to tell the interviewer in case they are intercepted.  Participants will also be asked to plan one of five randomly selected innocent tasks, such as buying two gifts for a friend from a local shop.  Just before the participant leaves the building, they will be intercepted by an interviewer and taken to a nearby room for questioning. The interviewer will be blind to which tasks are actually part of the study and the participant’s task is to deceive the interviewer successfully. The interviewer will first ask the participant about their intentions, followed by questions about any mental image that was activated during the planning of their task. Finally, participants will be asked to sketch a picture of their most dominant mental image of what it will be like when they complete their task. Participants will then return to the original room and complete a detailed post-interview questionnaire beginning with questions directly related to EFT, followed by questions adapted from the Memory Characteristics Questionnaire (MCQ, Johnson, Foley, Suengas & Raye, 1988) relating to the phenomenological characteristics of their most dominant mental image including perceptual details.

To assess participant’s EFT ability, participants will complete an episodic details task adapted from D’Argembeau, Ortoleva, Jumentier and Van der Linden’s (2010) study. The episodic details task requires participants to imagine a possible situation that they may encounter in the future (‘imagine something you will do on your next holiday’). Participants will be told to describe the specific event as if they were physically present in the situation including as many details as possible. Participants will then respond to a series of questions adapted from the MCQ (Johnson et al, 1988) indicating their phenomenological experience of the task.  In the previous study (study 1), this EFT task was the most predictive measure of the amount of details and number of words participants used, when describing their true and deceptive intention. Participants will also complete the revised Hexaco Personality Inventory (Ashton & Lee, 2009) in which they will rate 60 statements about themselves from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). This questionnaire measures six broad personality factors: Honesty-humility, emotionality, extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness and openness to experience.

Participants will then take part in the same ‘intent to deceive’ experiment as study 1, which is largely based on Granhag and Knieps (2011). Participants will be asked to plan a mock criminal event (placing a memory stick containing illegal material on a specific shelf in the physics section of the university library) and plan a cover story in case they are intercepted.  Participants will also be asked to plan one of five randomly selected innocent tasks, such as buying two gifts for a friend from a local shop.  Just before the participant leaves the building, they will be intercepted by an interviewer and taken to a nearby room for questioning. The interviewer will first ask the participant about their intentions, followed by questions about any mental image that was activated during the planning of their task. Finally, participants will be asked to sketch an image of their most dominant mental image of what it will be like when they complete their task. Participants will then return to the original room and complete a detailed post-interview questionnaire beginning with questions directly related to EFT, followed by questions relating to the phenomenological characteristics of EFT.

In part B of this study, we will ask a separate group of participants to rate the veracity of the verbal descriptions of the truthful and deceptive tasks provided in part A. Participants will also rate their confidence in their veracity judgements as well as the plausibility of the story.

In part C of this study, we will ask participants to rate the veracity of the sketches collected part A. We will also ask them to rate the abstractness of the sketches. This task is a replication of Calderon, Giolla, Ask and Granhag, (2018). Calderon et al. found that participants judged drawings of false intentions as more abstract than true intentions drawings.

attributes.title: Mindless math: the failings of fluency

q2.value: Asher Lawson, Richard P. Larrick, Jack B. Soll

q3.value: We ask participants to answer a problem and then self-report on the process they used to reach that answer.

q4.value:
H1a: The effect of numeric demands on the likelihood of responding correctly will be statistically mediated by differences in the rate at which respondents never add any numbers (mechanism option 1).




H1b: The effect of numeric demands on the likelihood of responding correctly will be statistically mediated by differences in the rate at which respondents add numbers, but do not use this sum (mechanism option 2).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: We use a 2-condition between-subjects design. Participants are placed in either the 'easier' or 'harder' numeric demands condition. They answer one item, and then self-report their cognitive mechanism.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The study will be placed on mTurk. There will be no exclusion criteria, except having previously completed a study related to this project.

q13.value: N = 600. We want each cell (easier / harder numeric demands X correct / incorrect response) to be populated sufficiently to facilitate meaningful statistical tests.

question.value: Numeric demands (easier vs harder)
What cognitive process the respondent self-reports having used (4 options). What answer the respondent inputs (and if this is correct or not). Demographic information (age, gender, education, race).

We will conduct two tests. First, whether we replicate the 'mindless math' effect (using logistic regression with correct as the DV and numeric demands condition as the IV). Secondly, we will input our data into Hayes' (2013) Process Model 4 using lavaan in RStudio, and test for the indirect effects of numeric demands on the likelihood of correct responding through different rates of selection of the first (no adding) and second (add, don't use) cognitive processes participants can choose to self-report. We will test for significance using the p-values from this mediation model.
